fields.headline: Pernod's friendly persuasion
fields.bodyText: Richard Burrows, managing director of Pernod Ricard, yesterday played down suggestions that relations with rival drinks group Allied Domecq had been frosty throughout their takeover discussions, which last month ended in an agreed £7.4bn offer from the French firm."We had very friendly discussions and all the time within the context of a friendly approach," he said. He conceded that due diligence disclosures by Allied had been limited, but added that they were sufficient for Pernod to construct its bid, which it is pursuing jointly with US group Fortune Brands. Pernod reported better than expected sales for the first three months of 2005, up 7% at €752m. Highlights included strong growth in China and a 45% sales volume increase in Pernod's Jacob's Creek Australian wine range in the UK, albeit at lower margins. A 1.8% decline in US volumes was disappointing, but Mr Burrows stressed it was due to one-off pricing and marketing changes on Seagram's gin last year.
